awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Evaluating the Cognitive and Educational Benefits of Mental Abacus Training
awd_abstract_narration:
Mental Abacus is a popular mathematics technique practices primarily in Asian countries in elementary school contexts. Mental abacus students begin by learning to make rapid arithmetic computations on a physical abacus and then learn to imagine moving the beads without the physical device. Young children can then rapidly add, subtract, multiply and divide large numbers. This project will compare mental abacus teaching to two other teaching methods in order to understand how it helps first and second grade students learn to compute and learn conceptual understanding of place value. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.  Investments are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring:  STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.
Prior work indicates the mental abacus computations are connected to visuo-spatial working memory. The project is a randomized experiment to compare the effectiveness of Mental Abacus, Singapore Math Curriculum and business-as-usual curriculum in grades 1 and 2 in multiple elementary schools.  Math outcomes will be measured with standardized test scores and four assessments (an in-house arithmetic fluency measure, the WIAT, the Woodcock-Johnson III, and a measure of conceptual understanding of place-value). A battery of cognitive measures and a measure of intervention fidelity will also be included. The project should result in understanding the effectiveness of Mental Abacus as a method for teaching and provide a foundation for larger scale work in the area.

por.por_cntn:
Mental Abacus (MA) is a popular arithmetic technique practiced mainly in Asian countries in which students learn to solve math problems by visualizing a physical abacus structure. Prior studies conducted in Asia have found that MA can lead to exceptional mathematics achievement in highly motivated individuals, and that extensive training over multiple years can also benefit randomly sampled students in standard classroom settings. In this grant project, we explored the benefits of short-term (one year) MA training to typical students in the US context.  We investigated the potential effectiveness of MA in the US context by conducting a one-year, classroom-randomized trial of MA instruction in a Northeastern public school. Classes were randomly assigned to either maintain their standard math curriculum (Common Core plus Singapore Math; Control) or receive a mixture of their standard math plus mental abacus training (MA).

We assessed performance during the first week of classes, before MA was administered, and near the final week of classes, after children in the treatment group had received a full academic year of training. The study had two main goals. First, we asked whether a group of US school children (N=180) would experience greater benefit from MA training than from equivalent hours of standard math curriculum. Second, we explored the claim, made by several recent studies, that even small amounts of MA training might yield benefits to visuo-spatial working memory abilities. Although spatial working memory is generally thought to be resistant to training via “far transfer,” these recent studies find significant differences in performance on classic tests of spatial working memory after only a few weeks of training. We reasoned that if these effects are reliable and robust enough to be of significance to educational practices, then they should also emerge in a longer study with a larger number of participants.

Overall, we found first that the first-graders children in our study were not able to master the abacus representation such that they could translate numbers between abacus and numeral formats. This limitation meant that they were missing one of the prerequisites for MA learning, and compromised their ability to see other gains from the technique. For the second-graders, one year was sufficient to acquire a basic understanding, but that this level of mastery yielded only the beginnings of measurable benefits to mathematics achievement: We saw at best hints of improvements in place value understanding, with no effects on arithmetic performance more broadly. Also, although we found that uptake of MA was mediated by students’ pre-existing spatial working memory capacities (see also Barner et al., 2016), we did not find evidence that one year of training was sufficient to augment working memory.  

These results have several important implications. First, they suggest that although longer term interventions likely benefit children, short-term MA interventions do not benefit children more than existing techniques, in this case the Singapore Math curriculum. While this result may be interpreted as a negative finding, it might also be taken as evidence that alternative approaches - which children may potentially find more enjoyable than existing techniques - can be deployed without sacrifice to learning. Despite focusing heavily on procedural learning of basic arithmetic operations like addition and subtraction, MA benefits children to the same degree as curricula designed to augment conceptual understanding.

Second, consistent with the findings of our previous NSF-funded work (Frank et al., 2012; Barner et al., 2016), our results indicate that MA is most easily learned by children with greater pre-existing spatial working memory capacity. Many previous studies have argued that MA relies fundamentally on representations in visuospatial working memory (Frank & Barner, 2012; Hatano, Miyake, & Binks, 1977; Chen et al., 2006; Hu et al., 2011; Tanaka et al., 2002). Our results support this claim.

This project afforded the opportunity to train a large team of PhD researchers and academic staff to conduct a large scale longitudinal randomized controlled trial. PhD students designed testing protocols, traveled to the research site, tested hundreds of participants, analyzed data, and contributed to the writing of a final report, soon to be submitted for publication.
